BuzzFeed's Analytics Tools:

Building tools to empower data-driven decision, learning, and experimentation



Background

BuzzFeed creates and publishes over 500+ videos, posts, and graphics a week to our owned & operated properties and many social platforms like Facebook or Snapchat. We get data back about how our content connects with our audiences from metrics like pageviews, shares, and retweets. The knowledge held in this data helps us to understand what resonates with them; consequently powers the feedback loop (create > publish > learn > iterate) for our content creators to make better, more engaging content.


Data plays an integral role in BuzzFeed's editorial and business, so how might we enable the data-decisions across the organization?


Opportunity

Empower the entire organization to make data-driven decisions with a suite of analytic tools that are built by a dedicated team of product managers, engineers, designers and data-scientist that are hyper-focused to adapt the ever-changing needs from our editorial and business stakeholders and users.


As the sole designer in the Reporting Tools team, I lead the design and execution of all the dashboards, slack notification, and training collaterals. For the last 1.5 years, I am the product manager in driving the strategy and vision for Search, Audience dashboard and improvements on the Content Insights dashboards.



-------------------------------------------------------------------------------



The user problems have evolved quite a bit for the last 2 years. Let's start from the beginning:


Before el dashboard...

- Accessing data was tedious. People were cobbling datasets across 3rd party tools and spreadsheets, and spending more time on hunting down data than doing the analysis. Our data analysts were drowned by similar data requests and questions from different parts of the company which could be better fulfilled by self-serving dashboards.

- Because of the high friction to get data, people resorted to subjective ways to set goals and make tactical decisions based on fragmented knowledge and anecdotal assumption. It was neither clear nor consistent which metrics were actually important to move the needle.



The goal at the time: Solving the breadline problems by making the most essential datasets in an easy, fast and well-organized design for our editorial users was the top priority.


Results: Content insight Dashboard

The first few dashboards addressed those pain points by providing key performance metrics for a given piece of content. The table-based design powered by a set of robust filters, search and sorting, is efficient and flexible for exploring the large dataset. Users can look up “What are the most popular videos about Béyonce?”, or “What are the most commented news post from last week?”, and then drill down to dive into the detail stats.

(Facebook Posts, Video Dashboard, Graphic Dashboard, Post Dashboard)



------------------------------------------------------------


0. Failed First Attempt

Known as the Content List, the first dashboard we built was based on an

assumption that a one-size-fill-all product would satisfy everyone's needs. The unclear use case along with the unforeseen engineering challenge forced us to kill the dashboard shortly after its completion. Since then, our team learned to be critical of product decisions and evaluated every project by the user impact and team effort before design and development.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------


As getting data about a piece of content became easier, our users started to wonder about the different type of problems:

- What content is doing well right now among our audience?

- How well is their content doing compared to historical?

- What is the exceptional performing content?

- Which content shows the early signs of going viral?

- What are the important "signal" we should act on and go after the success?"


The goal at the time: Surface noteworthy, actionable signals by showing real-time insights on outstanding and trending content to help our users to optimize the content success further: the content distribution team can fuel the viral content further by distributing to other platforms, channels or countries; while our content creators feel rewarded and motivated to push for success.


Result:

Designed signal-based products to communicate success and trending.


- 99 badges - A set of buttons for content that broken high benchmarks implemented across different slack notifications and dashboards.


- Trending Videos – A visual Hall-of-Fame for videos that have the highest velocity in Shares and Views growth. The treemap helps users to grasp the fastest growing content based on the size of the image.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------


Most of the outstanding content and viral hits that are beloved by our audience is a result of content experimentation. However, tracking the performance for any custom grouping of content based on a common subject or intent remained very difficult. Editorial leads often resorted to a manual process to log the data into a spreadsheet and aggregate the result.


The goal at the time: Facilitate the ideation and experimentation process by providing toolings to make tagging, searching and learning a grouping of content easier.


Result:

Create tools to help users to ideate and track experiment and through content discovery (Search), custom tagging (Experiment) and content intent analysis. (Jobs)


Search - A visual search tool that enables everyone to search and draw inspiration from our catalog of 3 millions of videos, graphics, and posts, so people can look up "What green-tea dessert videos we have made so far?"


Experiment - a workflow tool for creating and applying custom tags to a group of content, and see the aggregated performance data.


Cultural Cartography visualization and Job chrome-extension is an experimental project to group content based on intent (Make me laugh, Aspiring) and "job-to-be-done"



-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Despite easy access to data and detect outliers, our editorial leaders have a hard time tracking the overall health and long-term trends of our core distribution platforms, like BuzzFeed's owned and operated and Facebook. As the audience's media consumption and the distributed platform is evolving quite a bit in the past year, able to optimize our content outputs to maximize the returns in audience engagement becomes critical to our business.



The goal at the time: Provide tools to monitor the health of the core distributed platforms that enables our management and editorial lead to easily track short- and long-term changes, and make timely decisions on the editorial and distribution strategy to adjust the market changes.


Result: Develop a health platform dashboard for Facebook and O&O our two main distribution platforms. The dashboard consists of several time-series graphs that track the content output and the key engagement metrics side-by-side. Most of the metrics have a strong correlation where the changes in one metric could reveal the changes in another. One of the novels features is pinning, which let users click and mark any date across all graphs so the user can compare the changes of those metrics across the same point in time.

Pinning feature

Facebook health (image)

O&O Health (image)



-------------------------------------------------------------------------


While those big initiatives were happening, our team was also gradually expanding the dashboard suite by increasing our data coverage for the entire organization. Today, El Dashboard has grown into a suite of 12 dashboards and evolved into four categories of tools: Content insights, Signal, Discovery & experiment, and Platform Health.




-------------------------------------------------------------------------


Process:

A typical process often goes like this:


1. Define the problems by deeply understanding the user and business goals. The methodology and tools for this step include interview, workflow/product audit, design workshop, worksheets, and thought exercises.


2. Explore the solutions in a broad spectrum to validate its viability, feasibility, and usability. I utilize a mix of prototype methods from paper mocks, click-through screens, live prototype in code, spreadsheet and 3rd party products (Mode, Looker).


3. Refine and test continuously until that we land on a simple, effective and scalable design. With proximity to our users, I share the design iteration, prototypes, and beta versions of the build for feedback frequent and often.


*To ensure our tools can grow quickly and gracefully, I also establish a design system for the dashboard suites along the way, which includes the UI floorplan, UI pattern (an extension of BuzzFeed's Solid Pattern library), graph components and accessibility-friendly color palettes.


5. Ship, promote and preach!

To ensure the product or feature is discoverable and understandable, we deploy 3 pronged strategy to communicate to users effectively: in-app promotion, in-context product announcement, and in-person demo session. The tool we use includes feature highlight modals, user guides documentation, cheatsheets, FAQs and email.


6. Listen and learn from users.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------


Outcomes


El Dashboard continues to grow and thrive as the core analytic tools for the company. With over 600 active users a month, (35% of the entire organization), users are continuously relied on our tools to learn and make the data-driven decision every single day.


We recently expanded to support users in the Business division on growing our advertising, native contents and brands.


The dashboard helps our content creators and brands to refine out the viral hits one after another.






-------------------------------------------------------------------------



Things I Learned

- The designing for internal users is a luxury. We can have a very tight feedback loop to improve their products, opens to use "half-baked products" and gives us tons of feedbacks. We also know the ins-and-outs of their strategy changes and adapt our roadmap to meet their needs.


- I strongly believe in scalable UI architecture that placement of a UI is not an obituary decision.


- Data load and caching are a huge part of good user experience. For the audience dashboard, we experiment with data load because of percentile bucket which provides the much better result for our cases.


Learn to be a product managing


Building a product is only half the battle. Onboarding, education and continuous retent our users is the other half.



--------------------


My role: Sole product design lead. Also, product Manage all the content insights dashboards for 12 months. Team: a fantastic team of 1 designer, 1 products manager, 4 data scientists, 4 front-end engineers, 2 back-end engineers. n



-------------


How did everything start?


1 - Understanding the needs from both sides: Myself and fellow leads are in regular conversation with stakeholder and leaders in editorial and business org to understand the high-level goals and gaps in their pipeline. We also regularly talk to our users who user data in their day-to-day to make a decision.


2 - Evaluate each product ideas based on impact x effort framework I established for the team.


Effort - What does it take to build a feature?

- Are the data available? Can they be accessible programmatically? Are they in the frequency and granularity we want?

- What does it take to build this feature end-to-end from design, engineer, data scientist and product, support perspective? Is there a non-custom-build solution that would achieve the same result that is fast and cheaper?


Impact -

For internal users, we have the benefit of having an existing user pool, and a good understanding of their goals and needs. The questions we would determine which user group will benefit this feature, and how it may trickle down to benefit the company downstream.
